courses.learning_outcomes:
* *Learning Outcomes**

* Become familiar with key theoretical concepts such as the gaze, desire, intersectionality, as well as feminist, queer and transgender creative resistance to traditional gender hierarchies.
* Able to deconstruct media text, and understand their hidden meaning, especially in relation to cultural production and the construction of sexual and gender norms, and how they pertain to existing inequalities in society
* Critically engage with biased and stereotypical media representations related to gender and sexuality
* Possess knowledge about and appreciate works by female, queer and transgender filmmakers
* Understand, relate and apply key feminist film and media studies concepts to daily viewing and creative practices
* Conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on feminist film and media studies
* Design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
* Become familiar the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 by engaging directly with the SDGs 5 (Gender Equality) and 10 (Reduced Inequalities), and are motived to implement them and promote them.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lesson 1 Introduction: Feminist Film Theories, Queer Spectatorship, and Critical Literacy

Lesson 2 Feminist Film Theories: History and Key concepts (focus on the origin and background of the emergence of Feminist film theories and their contributions, related to SDGs 5 and 10)

Lesson 3 The Gaze, Desire, and Female Images (focus on representation of women as “marginalized / objectified groups”, and how biased media representation marginalizes them, related to SDG 5)

Lesson 4 After Mulvey: The Gaze, Feminist Spectatorship, and a screen of one’s own (focus on attempts to find new representations of women, related to SDG 10)

Lesson 5 What women can we see: Housewife, immigrants, old women, lesbians, and other (de)politicized identities (focus on representation of “marginalized groups”, and how biased media representation marginalizes them, related to SDG 5)

Lesson 6 Women in the Underworld: Sex, violence, and fetishism (focus on representation of “marginalized groups”, and how biased media representation marginalizes them, related to SDG 5)

Lesson 7 Women in Action Films: Sluts, victims, femme fatale, trophies, ass-kicking chicks, violent women, and action heroines (focus on under-representation and biased representation of women in the popular genre, and how it is changing, related to SDGs 5 and 10)

Lesson 8 Monstrous feminine: A Comparative Study of Women in Horror Films from Hong Kong, Japan, Thailand, Taiwan, and Hollywood (examining gender stereotypes and its relationship to gendered horror representation in media, related to SDG 5)

Lesson 9 The Imperial Gaze: (Post)coloniality, Geopolitics and Gender Representation (examining racism and its relationship to gender representation in media, related to SDG 5)

Lesson 10 Pornographic Bodies and Perverse Pleasure: Cult films, sexploitation, and pornography (focusing on representation of female sexuality, and how it is affected women’s lives, related to SDG 5)

Lesson 11 Gender in Production: Women in media industry, Visibility, and Recognition (examining the gender inequalities in media industry, and what is done to change them related to SDGs 5 and 10)

Lesson 12 “Girl Power” Feminism and Popular Culture: The rise of “women films”, Queer cinema, the trans-question, and intersectionality (focus on movements that strive for greater equality and diversity in representation of gender and sexuality, related to SDG 10)

Lesson 13 A Feminist Critic’s Guide to Active Watching (focus on critical reflections and possible actions to strive for greater equality and diversity, related to SDG 10)

courses.description: The course is conducted by the teaching staff from this Programme. The content of this course varies from semester to semester, but concentrates either on selected problems related to the encounter with other societies through experiential fieldwork, or on special issues in Gender Studies. Contents of this course will vary with instructors and students. Students are required to join all lectures and workshops to show their capacities in applying those theories, particularly the research skills and methodologies, learnt from different courses. They are requested to put their ideas into practice by engaging with the communities outside Hong Kong. It also aims to strengthen the relationship between teachers, the society, external stakeholders and students so that students' global citizenship is established and strengthened. It can also provide opportunities for the students to work in a team. They are required to submit an individual report afterwards.

courses.title: Media Representations of Minorities in Hong Kong
courses.description:
(UGEC3215 is double-coded with GDRS3214.)

How do we understand the notion of “minority”? And how does “minority”, look like, in cinema?

This course examines the rich tradition of critical film theory and provides students with an understanding of its main concerns and debates, concerning “minority” identities and subalternity. Addressing key discussions about media representations of “minority”, the course will look at the politics of representation and its impacts, both on- and off-screen. We will be looking at how media works to construct “the Other” in different contexts, and delve into important work which have inspired minority cinema, subaltern cinema, avant-garde cinema, local cinema, and independent cinema among other counter-movements, as well as recent re-conceptualizations and exploration of representations marginalized identities, positions, and experiences, local and abroad.

Across different systems of representation, from fine art to mainstream cinema to advertising, different groups, especially marginalized ones with little access to the mechanisms of production, have been constructed and existed as spectacle or passive object “to-be-looked-at,” in critical film theorist Laura Mulvey’s now often quoted words. Lacking representations both behind the camera and in front of it, how are the lives of different social “minorities” affected by biased media representations? How are stereotypes and biases created, disseminated, perpetuated, and reproduced through media, and to what consequences? Mulvey’s groundbreaking analysis of gendered looking relations in classical Hollywood cinema has since generated numerous analyses of the standings of different socially and culturally marginalized groups, such as ethnic minorities, queer communities, and people with disabilities, etc., as spectacle or passive object “in films cut to the measure of desire” of the dominant social groups.

What happens when “minority” artists, audiences, and theorists look back, and seek to rebel against such cinematic traditions by experimenting with alternative visual languages and narrative tools? Critics showed how different marginalized groups around the world attempt to take control of their positioning through viewing or using texts in their own ways, and by creating their own. Minority cinemas and independent creators have been actively carving out space to tell their own unique stories of lives at the margin in dramatically different cultural contexts, and these images are further complicated by engagements with them through the intersecting lens including ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, ability, queerness, and more.

In the course, we will look at how socially marginalized groups, such as gay and lesbians, transgender persons, ethnic minorities, women in different stages of their lives, people with mental illness, teenagers, the elderlyand many others are portrayed, and seek to expand their on-screen existence in Hong Kong media. In the exploration, we will engage with key questions in critical film studies, including spectatorship, authorship, popular culture, character stereotypes in genre films, self-representation, systems of media production, pro-sumer culture, (g)local cinema, alternative cinema, and new media. Students would be introduced to trailblazing works by “minority” filmmakers and media creators worldwide, and important cinematic and media movements that challenge the status-quo. Special focus will be placed onto important works in Hong Kong and Asia for critical examination and comparative studies.

Through critical exercise and reflection on notions such as power, diversity, equality, and freedom, the course aligns with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 by engaging directly with the SDGs 5 (Gender Equality) and 10 (Reduced Inequalities).

courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1

Introduction: What is “minority”? (SDG 5 & 10)

- Introducing the notion of “minority”

Week 2

Theories about Minority, Other, and Subalternity (SDG 5 & 10)

- Introducing theories about “minority” as state and status, and other related theories

Week 3

Construction and representation of minorities in media (SDG 5 & 10)

- Placing the discussion of “minority” within the realm of media, and explore the mechanism of constructing and recreating “minority” through media production

Week 4

Minority lives in Hong Kong: Who are they? (SDG 5 & 10)

- Understanding the notion of “minority” in the context of Hong Kong society and cinema

Week 5

Sexual minorities: The very different existence of gays and lesbians (SDG 5 & 10)

- Explore the different representations of sexual minorities (namely homosexual men and women) in Hong Kong cinema, and the possible reasons behind the different strategies of portrayal

Week 6

Gender minority: Transgender, transexual, transvestite, or… what are you? (SDG 5 & 10)

- Examine how the transgender community are subjected to biased and inaccurate portrayal, and how it hinders understanding and de-stigmatization

Week 7

Who has sexual agency and who don’t? Teenage sexuality and the asexual existence of children and older women (SDG 5 & 10)

- Examine how the sexuality of teenagers and older women are rendered invisible in media, and its consequences

Week 8

Problematic (gendered) existence: Mothers, divorcee, widows, and the “leftovers” (SDG 5 & 10)

- Examine how women of different statuses are (not) portrayed in media

Week 9

“Broken people”: Mental illness, disabilities, victims, and people at the bottom (SDG 10)

- Looking at how ablism and other hegemony at work in media to the exclusion of different social groups

Week 10

The constructed notion of “South-east Asian”: Who is a Hong Konger and the inconvenient racial others (SDG 10)

- Inspect how the construction of the “Hong-Konger identity” is done via the exclusion of certain communities in Hong Kong, focusing on racial differences

Week 11

Are they also one of us? New immigrants, indigenous people, and boat people (SDG 5 & 10)

- Continue to discuss the construction of the “Hong-Konger identity” via the exclusion of certain communities within the Chinese population of Hong Kong

Week 12

Talking back from the margin: The counter-narratives of minority cinema (SDG 5 & 10)

- Introducing efforts from different communities to change the narratives

Week 13

Presentation & Conclusion

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Talking Across Differences: Compassionate Communication in Action
courses.description:
Words can keep one another at arm’s length, while bringing people together. This paradoxical nature, coupled with the fact that we cannot not communicate, makes our interpersonal lives moderately challenging and, more often than not, a source of joy, fulfillment, and connection, as well as frustration, unhappiness, and even conflict.

In the 1960s, having witnessed humanity's capacity for both violence and care, clinical psychologist Marshall Rosenberg sought to develop Compassionate communication (also known as Nonviolent communication) to foster love, truth, and courage. This model enables people to stay connected with themselves and others by identifying and expressing their underlying basic needs, even during times of conflict.

Not only does Compassionate communication nurture connection, but it also provides various tools to shift the mode of influence from power-over to power-with in collaborative settings, contributing to a peaceful and inclusive future. In fact, Compassionate communication has been recognized by UNESCO as one of the best practices for nonviolent conflict resolution in both formal and informal education worldwide.

As working with people from diverse backgrounds becomes increasingly common, the ability to communicate across differences is essential. This course will cover all the essential concepts, processes, and skills of Compassionate communication for both personal and social life. Through interactive learning in the form of role plays, demonstrations, and real-life scenarios, the course will cultivate students' awareness of their needs and their ability to authentically express themselves. Students will learn to listen with empathy, make life-enriching requests, apologize without self-blame, navigate conflict, hold difficult conversations, and facilitate collaboration across differences.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GEWS2161.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will acquire
1. A deepened understanding of the underlying premises, processes, concepts and skills of Compassionate Communication.
2. An increased capacity to experience, identify and respond to the own emotions and feelings, as well as those of others.
3. Confidence and ease in authentic self-expression with care, orienting to others’ experiences with empathy, making life-enriching requests without demands, and navigating difficult conversations and conflicts with a collaborative mindset.
4. Openness and curiosity toward differences, along with a skill set for collaborating with people from various backgrounds.
courses.course_syllabus:
CLASS 1: The Basics of Compassionate Communication (I)

This lecture introduces how and why clinical psychologist Marshall Rosenberg developed Compassionate Communication (also known as Nonviolent Communication, NVC) in the 1960s and outlines its key premises. It contrasts three common types of communication— dialogue, debate, and persuasion—and characterises Compassionate Communication as a language modality that fosters dialogue. Additionally, it identifies four common language patterns that hinder connection and understanding.

CLASS 2: The Basics of Compassionate Communication (II)

There are four components of Compassionate Communication that enhance connection and clarity: observation, feelings, needs, and requests. This session will guide students in making clear distinctions between observations and evaluations, feelings and thoughts, needs and strategies, and requests and demands. Additionally, it will help students cultivate their “needs consciousness”, serving as a foundation for empathetic listening.

CLASS 3: The Power of Empathetic Listening

Empathetic listening goes beyond the mechanics of hearing words; it involves immersing oneself in the speaker's emotional landscape, understanding their feelings and needs, and responding with genuine care and understanding. In this session, participants will learn to distinguish empathetic from non-empathetic responses listening, and the power of empathetic listening in transforming conflict to connection.

CLASS 4: Practicing Empathetic Listening

Tuning into the inner world of another person is a skill that requires refinement through repeated practice. This session will provide students with four easy-to-follow frameworks for listening to others with empathy. It will also offer important advice on making empathetic guesses more colloquial and natural in daily conversations. In empathetic responses, we often ask questions to gain a deeper understanding of the other person's experience. This session will distinguish between the types of questions that strengthen connection and those that do not.

CLASS 5: Making Life-Fulfilling Requests

This week's topic focuses on making requests in Compassionate Communication, highlighting our interdependence in meeting needs through others. While making requests can feel daunting, the course examines how they invite contributions to our happiness and addresses challenges like fear of rejection and underestimating others' willingness to comply. We will explore barriers to making fulfilling requests and share strategies for clear communication to improve positive responses. The session will also cover handling unmet requests and understanding the needs behind a "no." The goal is to help participants feel more comfortable asking for what they need while remaining open to any outcome.

CLASS 6: Expressing Appreciation and Making Apologies Without Self-Blame

Expressing appreciation is often recommended by relationship coaches as a relational lubricant. However, through the lens of Compassionate Communication, our usual way of expressing appreciation can sometimes take the form of judgment, even if it’s positive. The issue with judgment—positive or negative—is its static language, which can cast others, and even ourselves, in stone. For example, saying “You are so generous” provides no context about what actions led to that acknowledgement or which needs were met. Similarly, apologies like “I’m wrong” or “I’m sorry” can also be seen as judgments that foster self-blame and diminish self-confidence. This lecture will explore how to express appreciation using action-oriented language and how to make apologies without self-blame while fully acknowledging our impact on others.

CLASS 7: Troubleshooting: Clearing What Stands in the Way of Using Compassionate Communication

Failure teaches success. In this lesson, we will address frequently asked questions and common pitfalls encountered on the journey of learning and practising Compassionate Communication. Understanding the challenges we face can transform setbacks into valuable learning experiences. We encourage you to engage actively by asking any questions related to communication and its daily-life applications. Together, we’ll explore strategies to navigate these challenges, enhancing both your understanding and practical skills in Compassionate Communication. Your inquiries will help deepen our discussion and foster a supportive learning environment.

CLASS 8: Navigating Cultural Differences in Communication Styles

This week’s topic explores the intersection of culture and emotions within Compassionate Communication. We’ll examine how cultural backgrounds shape perceptions, expressions, and management of emotions, focusing on the differences between individualistic and collectivistic cultures. This session will discuss how cultures define ideal emotions, prioritise emotional expression or suppression, and the impact on mental and physical health. Additionally, we will consider how cultural perspectives influence emotional interpretation, whether through individual expression or situational context. Ultimately, the goal is to enhance our awareness of how culture affects emotional experiences and apply this understanding to our Compassionate Communication practice.

CLASS 9: Dancing with Conflict (I): What and Why?

Conflict is an inevitable part of life, and while it can be intense and overwhelming, it also presents opportunities for growth and understanding. This week, we begin our exploration of conflict through the lens of Compassionate Communication. We will start by examining our own typical reactions to conflict and identifying our default modes of engagement. We will discuss how conflict arises from differing needs, values, and interpretations of situations, and how these differences can be opportunities to learn from each other. This lecture introduces the idea that all actions, including those that trigger conflict, are attempts to meet basic human needs. By understanding the underlying needs and values involved, we can begin to shift from blame and judgment to connection and resolution.

CLASS 10: Dancing with Conflict (II): 9 Skills to Navigate Conflict

Building on our understanding of conflict, this week we will explore the practical application of the "9 Skills" of Compassionate Communication developed by Jim and Jori Manske. These skills offer a framework for effectively navigating conflict, beginning with the vital "Zero Step" of being present and self-connected. We will emphasise the importance of self-empathy in managing reactions and remaining grounded. The lecture will cover inviting others into dialogue, creating a safe space, expressing ourselves honestly, listening with empathy, making clear requests, and acknowledging different perspectives. We will also discuss using gratitude, feedback, and confirmation to enhance communication and understanding. By applying these skills to past conflicts, we aim to build stronger relationships and navigate difficult conversations. Ultimately, the focus will be on gaining confidence in using these skills in daily life for more compassionate and effective interactions.

CLASS 11: How to Have Difficult Conversations?

We will explore four responses to disagreements: 1) blaming others, 2) blaming ourselves, 3) practising self-empathy, and 4) empathising with others. Each response will be detailed, and practical exercises will reinforce our understanding. We will also identify factors that contribute to challenging conversations, such as differences in positional and status power. Additionally, we will analyse the impact of holding an "Enemy Image" of others and how to transform this perspective through Compassionate Communication principles. Intimate relationships can bring both joy and pain, often prompting us to recreate bonds we had with caregivers or compensate for unmet needs. In these relationships, we learn to express our needs while respecting our partner's boundaries. This session will provide valuable tips from Compassionate Communication for every stage of romance—whether it’s attraction, navigating power struggles, commitment, or even breaking up. By understanding our responses and improving our communication skills, we can foster healthier, more fulfilling relationships.

CLASS 12: Collaborating Across Differences: Compassionate Communication for Team Work

Collaboration is widely regarded as an essential means and a long-cherished goal across various settings. In this session, we will explore the roles and types of facilitation, along with practical facilitation skills to enhance our collaborative efforts. We will guide you through the process of designing a meeting, including setting a clear purpose and desired outcomes, as well as selecting appropriate processes. Additionally, we will have a brief discussion on alternative decision-making systems beyond majority rule, which are more likely to address basic needs without creating opposition.

CLASS 13: Harvesting Co-Learning Experience

courses.title: Gender in China
courses.description: This course introduces gender as an analytical tool to study Chinese history from ancient times to the present day. It demonstrates how gender challenges mainstream historical analysis and explanations. The focus is placed on the changing meanings and practices of femininity/masculinity across time. Issues such as gender transgression, homosocial relationships, marriage, sexuality and reproduction will be explored, both to shed light on, and to question our familiar perceptions of China. By examining the interaction between historical context and gender politics, this course also provokes reflections on methodologies, sources and discourses.

courses.title: Gender, Sexuality and Race in Political Issues
courses.description:
The course will examine the relationship between the development of gender and sexual identities and that of the contemporary politics mainly in, but not limited to, Asian societies. We will look into how the contemporary politics and gender structures in the regions interplay and produce racial identities through the lens of gender. For example, the Korean-Japan and China-Japan dispute over issues of comfort women in World War II; Gender activism in Gaza and Arab Spring, the female suicide bombers in middle-East, and religious right-wing movements in Hong Kong and Taiwan. Students will learn how to examine the issues of gender and sexual identities and how they are deeply embedded within the global politics as well as local social mores.

Specifically, the course is divided into two parts. First of all, we will review the key theories of citizenship, war, democracy, nationalism, human rights and so on – through the lens of gender. Students are expected to learn the core theoretical debates and methods through reading key texts. The second part of this course will analyze these theories and debates through cutting-edge case studies. Topics will include comfort women, sexual violence in war, terrorism, female suicide-bombers and right-wing religious movements, human trafficking, grassroots feminist organizations, anti-war activism and so on. Students are expected to establish a more solid and critical range of views to examine these global issues and political controversies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
\* The ability to raise profound questions about social phenomena.
\* The ability to design research and analyzing a data to answer the question thus raised.
\* The ability to research both local and global including but not limited to politics, economy and culture.
\* The ability to analyze and possess the multicultural and interdisciplinary vision.
\* The ability of social practice: to learn the implications of sociological research for social change, political debates and innovation.
\* The ability to research the relationship between conception of peacemaking and social constructions of sexual and gender identities.
\* The ability to research and analyze the role larger political and social conditions play in perpetuating gender based harms, discriminations and exclusions.

courses.title: Gender, Sexuality and Health: Towards Diversity and Equity
courses.description: The course examines how health experiences and outcomes are shaped by gender and sexuality, with the intersecting influences of age and race. Topics such as health care inequalities, the medicalization of society, and feminization of medical control will be critically examined.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are expected to learn to critically assess the influences of gender and sexuality on health behaviours and health outcomes.
2. Students are expected to gain understanding of gender and sexuality theories from empirical examples in health and medicine.
3. Students are expected to learn to draw links between their daily experience and observation, and conceptual issues.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: This is an experiential course which demands sound planning and a high level of reflection on the part of the students. Before the start of the second year, the student is expected to have completed a three-month supervised internship in an NGO or a university-affiliated unit which is involved with gender-related services or advocacy work. Before the internship starts, the student will prepare her/his proposal, outlining the objectives of her internship, and the theoretical knowledge or insights it rests on. Finally, a final report will be submitted, in which the student demonstrates her/his depth of reflection on her/his field experience, as well as the extent to which theory and practice can be integrated. The student’s performance will be evaluated on the basis of his/her final report and the partnering organization’s assessment.

courses.description:
The course is intended to be the second part of a sequence of two courses that form a capstone of a student’s study in the programme. (For the first part, see GDRS4005; 3 units would be awarded for successful completion of GDRS4005 and GDRS4010.)

The course provides an opportunity for students to undertake supervised study on a selected topic of interest. Students will be led to examine aspects of the selected topic, conduct a critical literature review and a systematic investigation of the topic they have chosen. Students are required to regularly discuss with the teacher concrete findings in their research and submit written progress reports as scheduled by the teacher and a complete project report at the end of the term. Students will present their work in an academic mini-conference.

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Gendered Migration in Transnational Asia and beyond
courses.description: The course will investigate contemporary women’s transnational migration from developing countries to newly developed countries in Asia and beyond. We will look at Filipina, Vietnamese and Chinese women migrating to Taiwan, Korea, Japan and the United States for marriage and employment. We will discuss issues related to labor and marriage migrations, as well as trafficking in women, on both macro- and micro-levels. We are going to ask: how does the global economic restructuring shape the gendered migration today? What makes female labor different from male labor in the global labor market? What are push-and-pull factors that trigger these women to leave their hometown to be workers or wives in foreign countries? What difficulties do they experience after entering host societies and what impact would the migration flow bring to both laborer/bride receiving and sending countries? Moreover, we will explore the global market formation of transnational commodified marriages between women from developing countries and men from more developed countries. Taking the matchmaking industry in Taiwan and Vietnam for example, we will ask: how should we perceive the subjectivity of women who marry abroad through brokers? How could we challenge the assumption that the brokerage business in transnational marriage is part of human trafficking practice, and women involved in this activity are victims? To better address this issue, we may also need to address the question: what is trafficking in women? How are women represented in the global anti-trafficking campaign and how the politics of charity influences the state’s immigration policymaking and women’s transnational mobility? We will approach these issues from a critical perspective in order to challenge given social perception that ignores women's agency at work. Throughout the semester, we will read theoretical and empirical works from many disciplines, including anthropology, sociology, political economy and women's studies. In addition, we will read primary source materials including news reports, online forums and watch documentaries and film clips.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course aims to provide students a comprehensive understanding of how gender plays in people’s migration using Asia as an example. It also provides an introduction to key issues pertinent to migration and trafficking studies. Having taken this course, students are expected to 1) be able to point out the problems of current understanding of women as migrants; 2) be able to criticize existing knowledge constructing women as passive agents or victims in migration; 3) be able to point out injustice treatment (im)migrants would receive in migrant-receiving countries. To facilitate these achievements, students are requested to read all assigned materials before coming to class and actively participate in class discussions.

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Gender Development from a Lifespan Perspective
courses.description:
Humans all over the world are inevitably gendered, either voluntarily or involuntarily, in tangible behavior and in perception, from birth to death.
Indeed, it is difficult to identify an aspect of human existence, be it ability, health, preferences, beliefs or opportunities,that does not have some flavor of gender. These gender phenomena do not arise from nowhere in adulthood but can be traced from childhood following a complex interplay of social, cognitive, and biological processes. They manifest in rich forms at various points of development. This course tackles the study of gender from a human developmental perspective, with the aim of understanding how gender phenomena arise, develop and change from infancy to older age, how they can be described and how to explain them with an eclectic theoretical approach that balances various developmental forces. The course also emphasizes an understanding of the methodology in empirical studies of age-related changes and causes and consequences of behaviours. Students are expected to engage actively in the identification and analysis of the relevant issues in real life, both of others and their own. At the end of the course, students will gain a critical understand of the role of gender in shaping human development, gain insight into what has led them to become who they are, and be more informed about how to deal with gender phenomena constructively at various life stages.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of this course, students are expected to:
1. Be able to understand and evaluate the methodology used to study age-related changes and causes and consequences of behaviours.
2. Gain a critical understanding of the role of gender in shaping human development.
3. Gain insight into what has led them to become who they are.
4. Be more informed about how to deal with gender phenomena constructively at various life stages and in different walks of life.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course tackles the study of gender from a developmental perspective, with the aim of understanding how gender phenomena arise, develop and change from infancy to older age, how they can be described and quantified, and how to explain them with an eclectic theoretical approach that balances various developmental forces. Theories and findings will be drawn mainly from Developmental Psychology but will also come from other disciplines such as animal studies and biology. The course also emphasizes an understanding of the methodology used to study age-related changes and causes and consequences of behavior.

Part 1: Introduction to the World of Gender Development
1. What is a developmental perspective + Key concepts and methods
2. Gender phenomena in real life: across ages, across walks of life

Part 2:Describing Differences and Similarities Between the Sexes
3. Biological Foundations of Sex and Gender
4. Cognitive Differences Between the Sexes
5. Sex Differences in Personality and Social Domains

Part 3: Approaches to Explaining Gender Development
6. Biological Approaches
7. Social Approaches
8. Cognitive Approaches to Gender Development

Part 4: Social Agents of Gender Development
9. The Family as an Agent of Gender Development
10. The Peer Group as an Agent of Gender Development
11. The Media as an Agent of Gender Development
12. The School as an Agent of Gender Development

The teaching and learning approach will be a mix of teacher-guided and student-centred activities. Before class, students have to post short highlights (discussion points) concerning the assigned readings. Lectures will introduce the background knowledge of each topic and review the required readings. During class, students will be engaged in group discussions and presentations. The teacher and tutor(s) will monitor and guide the discussions. Towards the end of the course, students will submit a personal portfolio to summarize and analyse how gender has influenced their life to showcase their personal reflection and grasp of the scientific literature.

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Thesis
courses.description:
The course provides an opportunity for students to undertake a supervised research project on a selected topic of interest. Students will be led to examine aspects of the selected topic, conduct a critical literature review, formulate research methods that gather data to address the selected research question, analyze the data (if empirical), and discuss the conclusions and implications of the findings. Supervisors are expected to be experts in any discipline who are able to supervise a research project that includes gender/sex as one of the major components.
Students are required to regularly discuss with the supervisor about their research and submit written progress reports as scheduled by the teacher and a complete written thesis of about 8,000 to 10,000 words in length (excluding tables, figures, bibliographies, and appendices) at the end of the year. Students will present their work in an academic mini-conference.

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Gender Studies:Theory
courses.description: This course addresses the relation of feminism to women’s/gender studies and focuses on contemporary developments in feminist theory. How feminist theorists have understood the signifi cance of sexual difference will be considered and how feminism is articulated with theories of representation, subjectivity, and history will be discussed. In the process, how difference and differences work, conceptually and politically, paying particular attention to the complex relations of gender, racial, and class difference will be attended to. This course therefore provides a comprehensive introduction to the contemporary key approaches, theories and debates of feminist theory and the relationship of theory and practice.

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Gender Studies: Methodology
courses.description:
“Gender” is not only a social category but also a perspective of seeing the world. As a discipline, gender studies draws on a variety of knowledge in humanities and social science and shapes its methodology and methods to challenge existing hegemonic knowledge that is considered being produced scientifically. The purpose of this course is to acquaint students with the intellectual debate between feminist epistemology and scientific knowledge production as well as to equip them with the abilities of critical thinking about their methodologies and conducting research with proper methods. Topics include: 1) critical questioning of the validity of knowledge production, the power relations between the researcher and his or her research subjects, and the representation of the research and the researcher; 2) cautiously examining the influence of globalization on feminist research and the intersectionality among race, class and gender; and 3) innovatively connecting theory with praxis through participatory action and writing. We will begin with a brief introduction to the history and development of feminist research, followed by discussions on feminist methodologies by exemplary researchers. In the final weeks, we will shift our focus to the application of theory and groundbreaking feminist writing through collaboration.
To make sure students are capable of conducting their own research using a feminist framework, this course also requests students to conduct a mini study and engage in narrative analyses. After taking this course, students are expected to be familiar with feminist approaches of conducting research and able to reflect on the knowledge production of their own research in the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil & PhD Gender Studies, MPhil-PhD Gender Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. State the key issues and debates in feminist epistemology and methodology.
2. Understand the importance of developing feminist epistemology and methodology
3. Analyze the similarities and differences between feminist epistemology and methodology and those of traditional social sciences and humanities
4. Develop critical thinking skills to reflect on existing research methods for studies of social science and humanities.

courses.title: Contemporary Women’s Issues
courses.description: This course aims to introduce methods and approaches of Women’s studies for the understanding of Women’s issues in contemporary society. It shall examine a broad range of issues facing women today, including job segregation, gender stereotypes in education, double-burden of working women, health and globalization, as well as discrimination against middle-aged women, single mothers and new women immigrants. The course will also review the continuous development of the Equal Opportunities Commission and the Women’s Commission established by the government, and their impact on Hong Kong society.

courses.title: Making Change: Feminism, Civil Society and Social Transformation
courses.description: This course is for those who aspire to social justice but are short of skills and consciousness. Drawing on feminist and critical theories, and Nonviolent Communication, the course will explore the myths of human nature that stand in the way of a large-scale and sustainable social transformation, and discuss the dynamism between gender, feminisms and civil society. The first four lectures will lay a theoretical foundation that cultivates a need-based perspective, weaving the gap between the personal and the social. On that basis, the course will examine how feminist-inspired campaigns intervene into social issues of significance to contemporary world, namely space, body politics, neoliberalism, and institutional reform. Alternative practices such as restorative justice, shared economy, ecovillages and intentional communities, new ways of governance such as Holacracy and Sociocracy will be introduced.

6. Practice: Retelling a New Story and Reconnecting to Life that We All Share
7. Taking Action: Violent or Nonviolent or Both?
8. Social Trauma and Social Transformation
9. Practice: Self-Care & Inner Resources
10. Reconciliation and Justice: Exploring Transitional Justice
11. Sexual Violence: Exploring Restorative Justice

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Diverse Genders and Sexualities: crossing the public/private divide
courses.description: This course looks at the critical sites of gender/sexuality formations in different societies and the many meanings of gender/sexuality in globalized cultures by drawing on a cross-cultural perspective and a comparative approach. In particular, this course brings a cross-disciplinary dialogue to the influences of diverse genders and sexualities on everyday life. It argues that although diverse genders and sexualities are seemingly ‘private decisions’, there are also lots of ‘public dialogues’ about them. The course examines the lives of LGBTQI+ people in diverse domains of life, such as employment, education, and health care, and analyzes some contemporary development in policy and practice. As a whole, the course calls for reflections on living with differences in contemporary society.

courses.title: Gender and Work
courses.description: How is work different for men and women? Why does gender matter in shaping the experience of work? Beginning with these questions, this course explores the distinct positions of men and women in the workplace and in the labor markets and examines gender relationship, gender segregation and gender discrimination across a variety of research topics on farm work, factory work, migrant work, business, housework, service work, entertainment and leisure. We will be reading about, analyzing, and discussing diverse empirical studies on men and women as workers, homemakers, care workers, organizers, or entrepreneurs, which provide fresh ways to look at the relationship between gender and work. This course provides students with key concepts and theories about the gendered institutions of economic development, organization, migration, and culture. Based on lectures, class discussions, and analytical practices, this course will help students to be an independent thinker and educated reader of social issues from a gender perspective. Students are expected to acquire critical thinking and analytical skills to reflect on theories and research findings, and to evaluate social facts and trends with implications for education, policy interventions and public participation.

courses.title: Gender and Family
courses.description: This course explores the concept of the family as a gendered social construction, considering how the institution of the family perpetuates gender roles and how social changes transform the familial structure at the same time. The course puts a premium on feminist thoughts on the reproduction of gendered family. We’ll start with introduction to how family is formed in different cultural contexts, and then proceed to discuss how family and kinship can be redefined under the development of reproductive technology, transnational migration, and globalization. Topics will include familial formation in contemporary patrilineal/matrilineal societies, non-mainstream marriages like walking marriage and bride kidnapping practices, gendered division of labor in conducting housework, the social construction of motherhood, domestic violence, cohabitation, non-married family, single-parent family, gay family, surrogacy, and transnational adoption and so on.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Gender Studies
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: What is the Gender Lens for Family Studies and Why?
2. The Formation of Marriage: Historical and Anthropological Perspectives
- - The Principles of Marriage Formation
- - Deviation of Mainstream Marriage Types: Two Examples: Bridenapping (Central Asia) and Walking Marriage (China: Mosuo)
3. Division of Labor in the Household
- - Productive and Reproductive Labor
- - Gendered Paid/Unpaid Labor
- - Career versus Family
- - The gender politics in the Family
- - Labor Division between Same-sex couples
4. Constructing Parenthood: Motherhood
- - Overview of the feminist debate over motherhood
- - Motherhood as experience and institution
- - Motherhood as socially constructed
5. Adoptive Kinship: from Biology to Choice
- - Adoptive parenthood and maternal citizenship
- - Kinship and nationalism
6. Surrogacy and New Reproductive Technology
- - The feminist debate over surrogacy: liberation versus exploitation
- - Commodification of women’s bodies?
- - Surrogate motherhood
- - New kinship and gay parenting
7. Domestic Violence
- - Gender debate over domestic violence
- - The feminist paradigm
- - Intersectional perspective: race, gender, and class
8. Alternative Family Violence against Women
- - Honor killing
- - Dowry killing
- - Female genital cutting
9. Migration and Family: Migrant Mothers and Their Children
- - Global care chain
- - Transnational parenthood
10. Extramarital Relationship
11. Transnational Marriages and Families
- - Global hypergamy
- - Familial relationship
12. Alternative Families: LGBT
- - Debate over gay marriage
- - Power dynamics between married gay couples
- - Gay parenting
13. Conclusion

courses.title: Feminist Methodology
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to acquaint students with the intellectual debate between feminist epistemology and scientific knowledge production as well as to equip them with the abilities of critical thinking about their methodologies and conducting research with proper methods. Topics include: 1) critically questioning the validity of knowledge production, the power relations between the researcher and his or her research subjects, and the representation of the research and the researcher; 2) cautiously examining the influence of globalization on feminist research and the intersectionality among race, class and gender; and 3) innovatively connecting theory with praxis through participatory action and writing. We will begin with a brief introduction to the history and development of feminist research, followed by discussions on feminist methodologies by exemplary researchers. In the final weeks, we will shift our focus to the application of theory and groundbreaking feminist writing through collaboration.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students of MA in Gender Studies, MPhil-PhD Gender Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be able to state the key issues and debates in feminist epistemology and methodology.

2. Students will be able to understand the importance of developing feminist epistemology and methodology

3. Students will be able to analyze the similarities and differences between feminist epistemology and methodology and those of traditional social sciences

4. Students will be able to develop critical thinking skills to reflect on existing research methods for studies of social science
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Histories and the Development of Feminist Research

How did feminist research/gender studies become a discipline in the academia along with the development of feminist movements in the West?

2. Feminist Knowledge Production

How is feminist epistemology different from conventional epistemology and how it criticizes androcentric knowledge production in natural and social sciences?

3. Standpoint Theory

What is women’s experience? How can women’s experience be the object of knowledge?

4. The Politics of Location and Representation

What are Third World feminism and post-colonial feminism? How do they respond to the mainstream feminism in the West?

5. Intersectionality

Why is “intersectionality” important in gender studies? How does gender intersect with race, class, and etc.?

6. Postmodernism, Globalization and Transnational Feminist Research

How could postmodernism influence feminist epistemology and methodology? How could we think globally and from the South?

7. Research Methods in Gender Studies

Major research methods in social science will be covered, such as ethnography, interview, discursive analysis, focus group, oral history, and etc. Some reflection on traditional research methods in conducting social science research will also be introduced.

8. Political and Ethical Issues

Some important issues in conducting social science research will be discussed, including authenticity of the data, the power relationship between the researcher and the researched, and researcher’s reflexivity, ignorance, and emotions in the fieldwork.

9. Feminist Writing Culture

What is feminist writing? How does such writing challenge conventional androcentric writing but still guarantee the “objectivity” of research? Some conventional writing in social sciences and experimental writing in feminist research will be introduced.

10. From Theory to Praxis

Two issues will be discussed: how to connect theory and practice and how to conduct collaborative research.

courses.subject: GDRS
courses.title: Chinese Women and Development
courses.description: This course explores the distinct roles of Chinese women in social and economic development and examines the historical and regional diversities of women’s images based on various topics including work, family, organization, migration, culture and so on. Women have not only played an important role in various areas of economic activities, but also helped to shape family management, public participation, and consumption. This course points to a variety of women's living and working conditions in China, as well as their experiences of social changes brought about by patriarchal traditions, socialist rules, market reforms, and changing policies of family planning and migration. As a result, Chinese women have appeared in various research traditions differently as iron girls, laid-off workers, working sisters, left-behind women, flower vase, housewives, dama and so on. Based on lectures, class discussions, and analytical practices, this course will help students to be an independent thinker of ideological shifts, policy changes, and social transformations from a gender perspective. Students are expected to acquire critical thinking and analytical skills to reflect on theories and research findings on work ethics, urban-rural divide, family relationship, intimacy and romance, and consumerism.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MA Gender Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn social facts and social trends about gender and development in China.
2. Develop skills to explain and relate women’s roles and gender relations with social contexts and institutions of development.
3. Apply the theoretical perspectives to analyze the causes and effects of gender (in)equality in socioeconomic development.
4. Critically evaluate social issues and reflect on social policies with a gender perspective.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics and Content:

1. Women and development
WID WAD GAD

2. Strong women
Public sphere, private sphere, appearance, iron girls, desexualization, labor participation, sedimentary model, quality discourse

3. Working sisters and the Left-behind
Laid-off, rural-urban migration, suzhi, bargaining power, sidelines, multitasking, nurturing

4. Reliable daughters
Son preference, filial piety, investment, maturity and obedience, uxorilocal marriage patrilineal, matrilineal, Sex ratio, girl power, family planning,

5. Marginalized Citizens
Land, housing, property rights, unitary household model, bargaining model

6. Female leaders
Public participation, ideal womanhood, lean in, structural constraints

7. Mothers and homemakers
Family planning, fertility desires, tiger mothers

8. Fairy brides
Marriage, divorce, marriage cross borders, deinstitutionalization, individualization, privatization, marriage preference, marriage market

9. Flower vase and commodity
Consumption, feminization of women, cosmetic surgery, post-feminism, radical feminism

10. Romantic or pure partner
Purity, sex, love, affairs, intimacy, resource inequality, emotional emancipation

3. Critically examine and evaluate the relevant laws, legal principles and judgments including the courts’ approaches to gender issues or related disputes.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand how gender played an important role in the course of history and interwove with social, cultural, economic and political forces;
2. Analyze history from gender perspectives and challenge mainstream historical interpretations with a variety of theories and methodologies; and
3. Develop multiple perspectives to understand gender issues and increase gender awareness about existing values and perceptions.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Historiography and Key Themes in Gender and History
2. Feminism and the Women’s Movement 1: The Birth of Chinese Feminism
3. Body Politics 1: Foot Binding and the Anti-Foot Binding Movement in late Qing and Republican China
4. Body politics 2: Prostitution and Regulation
5. Men, Women and Modernity
6. The New Woman
7. Feminism and the Women’s Movement 2: Women and Nationalism
8. Gender and War: Images of Women
9. Gender and War 2: Roles of Men and Women
10. Feminism and the Women’s Movement 3: Local, Regional and Global Women’s Solidarity Movements
11. Women in Maoist China (1949-1976) 1: Marriage Reform in the early PRC
12. Women in Maoist China (1949 – 1976) 2: Work and Life in Socialist China
13. Hong Kong : Gender and Colonialism
courses.feedback_evaluation: I value and welcome your feedback. You can write me an email or talk to me about how the course can help you learn better.

courses.title: Psychology and Gender
courses.description: This course reviews theoretical and empirical perspectives of the psychology of gender. Frequently studied or currently debated gender similarities/differences will be examined. Major biologically, socially and cognitively-oriented theoretical frameworks as determinants of gender development and dynamics will be introduced. Biological and socialization processes and their consequences will be explored in relation to individual development, education, work, and mental health; and related research findings will be critically reviewed.　The course will focus on using class as well as current issues in the study of gender psychology, such as gender dysphoria and sex segregation, as illustrations. (Not for students who have taken PSYC3640).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Gender Studies
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The history of the psychology of gender; Sex and gender
2. Methods and approaches in the psychological study of gender
3. Common experimental approaches and methods to measure gender differences
4. Describing differences and Similarities Between the Sexes
5. Biological mechanisms of gender development
6. Social approaches to explaining gender development
7. Cognitive approaches to explaining gender development
8. Topic issue: Gender-typed play and preferences in childhood
9. Topical issue: gender dysphoria
10. Topical issue: gender segregation in education
11. Topical issue: gender dynamics in interpersonal interactions
12. Topical issue: Sexual orientation
13. Topical issue: Explicit and implicit gender stereotyping
courses.feedback_evaluation:
a. Course and teaching evaluation survey will be conducted in the second last week of the course. Students are reminded of their responsibility and right to give feedback to facilitate enhancement of the course.
b. Students are welcome to give feedbacks to the course teacher at any time.

courses.title: Gender and Media in the Digital Age
courses.description: As digital media becomes a pervasive presence in our daily lives, we experience, construct, and reinforced gender and social identities through interacting with different forms of media. This class will examine how media mediates and represents gender and sexual identities in the digital realm. From a transdisciplinary perspective, students will study how media and new technologies intervene in the public and intimate spheres to empower people with choices and reinforce social inequalities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Gender Studies
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Basic concepts – Ways of seeing
3. Gender in Media (1) – Advertising, Magazines, Gender Roles and Gender Ideal
4. Gender in Media (2) – Gender on TV
5. Gender in Media (3) – Gender in Films
6. Gender in Media (4) – Cantonpop, Stardom, and Gender
7. Queering Media (1) – Gender trespassing and queer rebellion
8. Queering Media (2) - Cross-dressing in Cantonese opera and drag performance (Guest lecture)
9. Geopolitics and Gender representation
10. Media and the representation of (gendered) violence
11. Gender in Production (1) - Women in media industry, Visibility, and Recognition
12. Gender in Production (2) - Gaga Feminism and #metoo
13. Conclusion
